title-group.article-title: Updating the biologically based dose-response model for the nasal carcinogenicity of inhaled formaldehyde in the F344 rat

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Chronic inhalation of formaldehyde by F344 rats causes nasal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). This outcome is well-characterized: including dose-response and time course data for SCC, mechanistic endpoints, and nasal dosimetry. Conolly et al. (Toxicol. Sci. 75, 432–447, 2003) used these resources to develop a biologically based dose-response (BBDR) model for SCC in F344 rats. This model, scaled up to humans, has informed dose-response conclusions reached by several international regulatory agencies. However, USEPA concluded that uncertainties precluded its use for cancer risk assessment. Here, we describe an updated BBDR model that addresses uncertainties through refined dosimetry modeling, revised analysis of labeling index data, and an extended dataset where both inhaled (exogenous) and endogenous formaldehyde (exogF, endoF) form DNA adducts. Further, since Conolly et al. (ibid) was published, it has become clear that, when controls from all F344 inhalation bioassays are considered, accounting for over 4000 rats, at most one nasal SCC occurred. This low spontaneous incidence constrains possible contribution of endoF to the formation of nasal SCC via DNA reactivity. Further, since both exogF and endoF form DNA adducts, this constraint also applies to exogF. The revised BBDR model therefore drives SCC formation through the cytotoxicity of high concentration exogF. An option for direct mutagenicity associated with DNA adducts is retained to allow estimation of an upper bound on adduct mutagenicity consistent with the lack of a spontaneous SCC incidence. These updates represent an iterative refinement of the 2003 model, incorporating new data and insights to reduce identified model uncertainties.

body.p: While formaldehyde occurs naturally in cells as part of 1-carbon metabolism, inhalation of formaldehyde at 6 ppm and above is cytotoxic and causes nasal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) in F344 rats (Casanova et al., 1994; Kerns et al., 1983; Lu et al., 2011; Monticello et al., 1996). In rats exposed to 2 ppm inhaled (exogenous) formaldehyde (exogF), the concentration of deoxyguanosine (DG) DNA adducts due to endogenous formaldehyde (endoF) is twice the concentration due to exogF (Yu et al., 2015). Concentrations of exogenous DG and DNA-protein crosslink (DPX) adducts are predicted to exceed the concentrations of their endogenous counterparts at about 6 and 2 ppm, respectively (Conolly et al., 2023). Thus, the SCCs occur in an environment of chronic cytotoxicity, with consequent regenerative cellular proliferation (RCP), and high levels of exogF adducts of DNA and doubtless other cellular constituents (Conolly et al., 2003; Lu et al., 2011). While the formation of DNA adducts suggests a potential for promutagenic effects, SCCs were not seen at the noncytotoxic concentrations of 0.7 and 2.0 ppm formaldehyde (Monticello et al., 1996). Reviews of the MOA of formaldehyde carcinogenicity (McGregor et al., 2006; Thompson et al., 2020) both conclude that the rat nasal SCCs are primarily associated with cytotoxicity.

As a high production volume chemical causing nasal tumors in rats, concern for potential carcinogenic effects of formaldehyde in humans led to detailed studies of the rat tumors and mechanistic endpoints. Dose-response and time-course data were obtained (Heck et al., 1990; Monticello et al., 1996; Morgan 1997). This extensive database enabled Conolly et al. (2003) to develop a biologically based dose-response (BBDR) model for the rat nasal SCC. This model consists of 3 linked submodels. First, an anatomically realistic, 3-dimensional (3D) reconstruction of the rat nasal cavity was used with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) modeling to describe nasal airflow and the flux of inhaled formaldehyde into nasal mucosal tissue. Second, a tissue dosimetry model described formaldehyde input from the nasal cavity, clearance in the mucosal tissue, and the formation of DPX. Finally, a 2-stage clonal growth (CG) model linked the DPX burden and a data-driven description of RCP with the mutation of normal cells into cells with one procarcinogenic mutation (I cells) and with I cell mutation to form tumor cells that grow into clinically observable tumors.

The BBDR model, scaled up to humans (Conolly et al., 2004), was well received internationally (Health Canada, 2001; Liteplo and Meek, 2003; MAK Commission, 2002; WHO, 2002). However, several groups (Crump et al. 2008, 2010; Subramaniam et al. 2007, 2008) identified uncertainties. These were summarized by USEPA (2022, p. 2 − 70):

list-item.p: Confidence in formaldehyde airflow and flux CFD model.
Uncertainties in the formaldehyde DNA adduct modeling.
Uncertainty and variability in the rat cell labeling index (RCP) data.
Use of Hoogenveen approximation (Hoogenveen et al., 1999) to the exact solution of the 2-stage clonal growth model
Assumption that rat nasal SCC are rapidly fatal.
Uncertainties in assumed division and death rates of initiated cells

body.p: This report describes an update to the BBDR model of Conolly et al. (2003) that is responsive to these uncertainties. In addition, the updated model describes the role of endogenous formaldehyde in the formation of DNA adducts and a significantly revised treatment of control tumors. Conolly et al. (2003) described a control tumor incidence that was independent of formaldehyde. Inclusion of endogenous formaldehyde, in the current work, raises the issue of how the control tumor incidence should be related to endogenous formaldehyde. Another concern is that, while Conolly et al. (2003) identified 13 nasal SCCs in control F344 rats, only 1 of these was from an inhalation study (Subramaniam et al., 2007). Recently, the USEPA has suggested that this single tumor should not be used for the BBDR modeling (USEPA, 2022). The revised model therefore drives tumor formation primarily through cytotoxicity. This eliminates the need for a control incidence. However, a promutagenic effect of the DNA adducts is included, allowing the revised model to describe a small spontaneous incidence consistent with the lack of observed SCCs in the control animals. These revisions represent an iterative refinement. As model uncertainties are addressed and as new, relevant data become available, the fidelity with which the model maps to the relevant biology, and in this case, the relevant carcinogenic behavior, increases (Kell and Knowles, 2006).

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: The BBDR model (Figure 1) describes both the dosimetry (pharmacokinetics; PK) and subsequent tissue response (pharmacodynamics; PD) linking formaldehyde exposure with nasal tumor development in the F344 rat. The dosimetry component includes CFD and tissue pharmacokinetic modeling (Conolly et al., 2023). The pharmacokinetic modeling describes the formation of DNA adducts due to both endogenous and exogenous formaldehyde. The tissue response component describes the population of target cells and how mutations of these cells, as functions of both DNA adducts and cell divisions, lead to tumor formation. This progression from normal cells to tumors is described by a 2-stage clonal growth model (Moolgavkar et al., 1988). This new work builds on the prior BBDR model for the nasal carcinogenicity of formaldehyde in the F344 rat (Conolly et al., 2003).

caption.p: BBDR model for the inhalation carcinogenicity of formaldehyde in the F344rat. CFD modeling provides accurate, site-specific prediction of flux of formaldehyde from inhaled air into nasal mucosal tissue. Inhaled, together with endogenous formaldehyde, forms DNA adducts and is cytotoxic at high concentrations. The adducts are interpreted as a dose-surrogate for pro-carcinogenic, mutagenic effects. Regenerative cellular proliferation after cytotoxicity/cytolethality increases the rate of cell division. These key events increase the rate of mutation, leading from normal cells to cells with one mutation and then, with a second mutation, to the formation nasal tumor cells. A time delay (Table 4) is used to account for the interval between birth of a single tumor cell from its 1-mutation precursor and appearance of the clinically detectable tumor. Abbreviations: BBDR, biologically based dose-response; CFD, computational fluid dynamics.

sec.p: Computational modeling of a biological system must seek a balance between describing the relevant mechanistic biology in detail and development of a system of equations that are computable in a reasonable amount of time and with identifiable parameters (Walpole et al., 2013). The goal of the current work was to describe in the model only the major determinants of dose-response behaviors for key events and for tumor development and, if needed, to make risk conservative choices to fill data gaps. When the supporting dataset contains extensive dose-response and time course data, as is the case with formaldehyde, this approach will support development of a model capable of providing health protective predictions of risk. This approach is consistent with the mode of action framework as described by Dellarco and Fenner-Crisp (2012) and is also consistent with the preferred default approach to cancer risk assessment in the USEPA Guidelines for Carcinogen Risk Assessment (USEPA, 2005).

sec.title: Nasal geometry
sec.p: An anatomically accurate, 3D reconstruction of one side of the nasal passages was developed for an adult male F344 rat. The reconstruction was originally created from tracings of airway outlines by Kimbell et al. (1993, 1997) and used in prior formaldehyde dosimetry modeling efforts (Kimbell et al., 2001a,b). For subsequent studies including this one, the 3D surface geometry of the original rat model was smoothed using the medical imaging software Mimics (Materialise Inc, Leuven, Belgium) to permit more stable numerical computations (Schroeter et al., 2014). Bilateral symmetry was assumed for the left and right nasal passages. All reported surface areas were doubled to reflect both sides of the nose.

sec.title: Regions of interest
sec.p: The rat nasal passages were assumed to have a uniform mucus layer over all surfaces, except for the non-mucus-coated (dry) squamous in the nasal vestibule. Approximate locations of mucus-coated and non-mucus-coated squamous epithelium and the sites where cell proliferation data are available (see Figure 1 in Monticello et al. (1996)) were mapped onto the smoothed rat surface model according to descriptions by Schroeter et al. (2014).

Mapping of squamous epithelium was necessary as this type of epithelium is not considered to be at risk of neoplastic transformation due to formaldehyde (Morgan et al., 1986). The squamous epithelium is therefore excluded from the BBDR modeling of tumor risk. The distinction between mucus-coated and non-mucus-coated squamous was made to enable the use of appropriate boundary conditions.

The sites where cell proliferation was measured included the anterior lateral meatus (ALM), posterior lateral meatus (PLM), anterior midseptum (AMS), posterior midseptum (PMS) and medial maxilloturbinate (MMT). Mapping the cell proliferation sites allowed prediction of flux for these sites to be correlated with site-specific measurements of cell replication (further described below under “Cell division”).

sec.title: Airflow and formaldehyde uptake simulations
sec.p: CFD simulation methods used here were previously described by Schroeter et al. (2014). Briefly, a hybrid computational mesh consisting of approximately 4.8 million tetrahedral and prism elements was developed using the commercial software ICEM-CFD (Ansys, Inc, Canonsburg, Pennsylvania). Steady-state inhalation airflow simulations were conducted using Fluent (Ansys, Inc) assuming laminar, incompressible flow. A no-slip boundary condition (airflow velocity is zero at the airway walls), a zero-pressure condition at the nostril, and a negative pressure specified at the outlet were used. A symmetry boundary condition (zero-shear slip condition with zero perpendicular velocity) was applied to the region in the nasopharynx that was open to the other nasal side. Since the rat model only contained one side of the nose, all simulations were run at half the target airflow rate. An airflow simulation was conducted for resting breathing using a steady-state target airflow rate of 0.576 l/min, corresponding to twice the estimated minute volume of 0.288 l/min (Kimbell et al., 2001a). A separate airflow simulation was also conducted at a steady-state target rate of 0.288 l/min so that formaldehyde nasal uptake predictions could be compared with the experimental data from Kimbell et al. (2001a). Mass balance errors for all airflow simulations were calculated as 100*([mass of air entering nostril(s)] − [mass of air exiting outlet])/([mass of air entering nostril(s)]).

Formaldehyde transport simulations were solved using Fluent (Ansys, Inc) assuming transport was decoupled from airflow due to low vapor concentration, with an exposure concentration of 1 ppm at the nostril and a first-order uptake boundary condition on all airway walls in which formaldehyde flux (Flux) was assumed proportional to its concentration near the airway wall (Cair) using the equation Flux = k*Cair. The first order mass transfer coefficients (k) were 0.41 cm/s and 4.7 cm/s for non-mucus-coated epithelium and mucus-coated epithelium, respectively (Kimbell et al., 2001a). Due to the linear nature of the boundary condition, flux values at other exposure concentrations can be scaled accordingly. Mass balance errors for uptake simulations were calculated as 100*([mass of formaldehyde entering nostril(s)] − [mass of formaldehyde exiting outlet] − [mass of formaldehyde absorbed on airway walls])/(mass of formaldehyde entering nostril(s)).

sec.title: Flux calculations and binning
sec.p: User-defined functions were written and compiled into Fluent to compute wall mass flux (ie, the rate at which mass is absorbed) on every element of the surface mesh. For a given region of interest, average flux was computed by summing mass flows (mass/time) on all elements in the region and dividing by the surface area of that region. Flux values had units of kg/m2-s as Fluent outputs and were converted to pmol/mm2-h. These calculations were applied to predicted flux for the six regions at which cell replication was measured and for the entire nonsquamous epithelium. For this latter calculation, the nonsquamous epithelium was partitioned into 20 flux bins following the approach of Kimbell et al. (2001b). Briefly, the full flux range from minimum and maximum values across the entire nonsquamous epithelium was divided into 20 equally spaced ranges to define each flux bin. Average flux and the corresponding surface area of each bin were calculated. All fluxes were breath-averaged by dividing by 2, assuming zero flux on exhalation and equal-length inspiratory and expiratory phases of the breathing cycle (Figure 2, Table 1).

caption.p: Lateral (top) and medial (bottom) views of the F344 rat nose. CFD-predicted flux of formaldehyde from inhaled air into the nonsquamous tissue lining the nasal cavity is depicted, as indicated by the legend. The highest fluxes are closer to the nostril. The lines depict isobars of flux and illustrate how the complex airway geometry of the rat nose strongly influences the site-specific uptake of formaldehyde from air into issue. The surface area between any 2 adjacent isobars defines a “flux bin.” The range of predicted fluxes on nonsquamous epithelium, from lowest to highest, was divided into 20 equal segments, thereby defining 20 flux bins (Table 1). The bins with highest fluxes are relatively small in surface area, with correspondingly fewer cells, while the bins with lower fluxes are larger, and account for most of the cells. Cytotoxicity, DNA adducts, and tumors are all nonlinear functions of flux and thus tend to occur in the bins with higher flux. Gray regions designate squamous epithelium, which is not considered to be at risk of neoplastic transformation due to formaldehyde (Morgan et al., 1986). Abbreviation: CFD, computational fluid dynamics.
Flux bins and cells per bin

sec.title: Tissue dosimetry and DNA adducts
sec.p: Conolly et al. (2023) described computational modeling of the formation of DG and DPX adducts of DNA due to both endogenous and exogenous formaldehyde. This adduct model is used here, as a component of the BBDR model, to calculate the flux- and time-dependent burdens of DNA adducts in each flux bin. Endogenous adducts are formed throughout the lifetime of the rat and so are not, technically, part of the dosimetry of exogenous formaldehyde. However, as described by Conolly et al. (2023), endogenous and exogenous formaldehyde compete for saturable intracellular metabolic clearance. The concentration of endogenous formaldehyde can increase due to this competition, and both endogenous and exogenous formaldehyde contribute to adduct formation as functions of their intracellular concentrations (Conolly et al. 2023).

To achieve computational efficiency, the DNA adduct concentrations were precomputed and stored as text files that are used as the BBDR model runs. These files contain hour-by-hour descriptions, for each flux bin, of the total concentrations of adducts. Endogenous and exogenous adduct concentrations are summed to define the total adduct concentration, which is used as a driver for mutation. In Conolly et al. (2003), an adduct file was simply a 20 × 24 array, holding time-dependent adduct concentrations for each hour of the 24-h day for each of the 20 flux bins. The involvement of both endogenous and exogenous formaldehyde and the competition between them for saturable clearance (Conolly et al., 2023) complicates the structure of the precomputed adduct files. These are constructed as follows:

Separate adduct files are developed for (background) environmental exposure with a constant concentration and for bioassay exposures, which are 6 h/day, 5 days/week. The background file is used for the portions of rat lifetime before the start of the bioassay, after it ends, and for each 2-day weekend while the bioassay is ongoing. For most cases relevant to the current work, the background exposure level is 0 ppm but, because of endogenous formaldehyde, there is nevertheless an adduct burden.

For both background and bioassay exposures, preparation of an adduct file requires that the concentration of endogenous adducts be computed with and without exogenous exposure: The quantity ADDendog—ADDendogB is then used to track the increase in endogenous F that occurs when exogenous and endogenous F compete for the saturable metabolic clearance (Conolly et al., 2023). Note that ADDendogB is a constant, since it is not a function of exposure to exogenous F.

Exposure to exogenous formaldehyde was described as starting at 10 am and lasting for 6 h, for 5 days/week, consistent with the rat bioassay protocol (Monticello et al., 1996). Prior to the start of the bioassay and after its end, the adduct files described only endogenous adducts. Parameter values for the adduct dosimetry modeling were as described by Conolly et al. (2023) except that flux inputs of exogenous formaldehyde were as shown in Table 1.

sec.title: Overview of the CG model
sec.p: The CG model specifies two procarcinogenic mutations for tumor development. Mutations occur when cells divide, with every division having an associated probability of mutation. Mutation of normal (N) proliferating cells gives rise to intermediate (I) cells having one mutation. A 2nd mutation can occur when an I cell divides, producing a tumor cell that, after a time delay, becomes a clinically detectable tumor (Moolgavkar et al., 1988).

The total rate of mutation increases when the probability of mutation per division is greater than zero and the rate of divisions increases, as with cytotoxicity and RCP. Alternatively, with a constant rate of division, the total rate of mutation increases if the probability of mutation per division increases. Formaldehyde forms DNA adducts but these adducts have not, to our knowledge, been shown to cause procarcinogenic mutations (Nakamura et al., 2014). For the BBDR modeling, we consider them a biomarker of exposure for promutagenic effects, whether such effects are due to the adducts or to another, unknown mechanism. Exogenous formaldehyde, at sufficiently high concentrations, is cytotoxic, with RCP replacing killed cells (Conolly et al. 2002). Cytotoxicity resulting in cell death thus increases the number of cell divisions. In addition, DNA-reactive species occurring in the cytotoxic environment contribute to the rate of mutation (Degrandi et al., 2010; Saquib et al., 2012). Cytotoxicity, thus, also contributes directly to the probability of mutation per cell division, in addition to its causing RCP. This mutagenicity of the cytotoxic environment is discussed more fully below. In summary, formaldehyde can increase the rate of mutation toward tumor formation through mutagenic consequences of cytotoxicity (eg, DNA adducts, cytotoxicity-driven RCP).

sec.title: Cell division
sec.p: A rich time course and dose response dataset describing replication of N cells in the rat nasal mucosa, the unit length labeling index (ULLI) (Table 2), was developed by Monticello et al. (1991, 1996). The average values of these data, as a function of CFD-predicted flux, show a low dose decrease in labeling, below the control level. At higher doses, the same dataset shows labeling increasing to well above control levels. The increases reflect RCP subsequent to cytotoxicity. Overall, the averaged values depict a J-shaped dose-response curve, resulting from low-dose inhibition and high-dose stimulation of cell replication. This behavior is clearly illustrated in Figure 3 of Subramaniam et al. (2008).

caption.p: Top left, Number of cells at risk in rat nasal mucosa; calculated using a Gompertz function (Conolly et al., 2003). Adult number of cells at risk is reached at about 20% of total lifespan. Top right, Net change in number of cells per hour during rat lifetime. Bottom, Time-dependent division rate constant (α) that supports net change in cell number when β = 3.5e−4/h. Note that, in adulthood, above about 5000 h, α = β.
Uniform length labeling index (ULLI) as a function of flux and sampling time

fn.label: a
fn.p: CFD-predicted flux (pmol/mm2/h). Each flux value is the average of the fluxes predicted for 5 sites in the rat nose (ALM, PLM, AMS, PMS, MMT) at which ULLI was measured (Monticello et al., 1991; 1996). The 5 flux values correspond to inhaled concentrations of 0, 0.7, 2.0, 6.01, 9.93, and 14.96 ppm formaldehyde.

fn.label: b
fn.p: ULLI were measure at 0.14 through 6.0 weeks using injected 3H-thymidine with sacrifice 2 h after the injection. (Monticello et al., 1991).

fn.label: c
fn.p: ULLI were measured at 13 through 78 weeks with 5 days of exposure to 3H-thymidine using osmotic minipumps (Monticello et al., 1996). Note how the ULLI values for 13–78 weeks are larger than those obtained at 0.14–6.0 weeks, reflecting the longer duration of 3H-thymidine labeling (120 h) when using osmotic minipumps.

sec.p: ULLI was measured in the ALM, PLM, anterior medial septum (AMS), posterior medial septum (PMS), and medial maxilloturbinate (MMT) (Monticello et al., 1991; 1996). Sampling time points were 1 day, 4 days, 9 days, and 6 weeks (Monticello et al., 1991) and 13, 26, 52, and 78 weeks (Monticello et al., 1996). For the ULLI measurements through 6 weeks, 3H-thymidine was injected, while subsequent measurements used osmotic minipumps implanted for 3 says. The analysis of these data by Conolly et al. (2003) was criticized by Subramaniam et al. (2007) as introducing unacceptable uncertainty. In response, we have developed a simplified approach that avoids assumptions about the quantitative relationship between the injection and osmotic minipump data. The new analysis also maintains the time-dependence of the data, which was not used explicitly in the previous analysis.

The total number of N cells in the rat nasal cavity, 4.4793e7, was calculated as the product of the total nonsquamous surface area (1523 mm2; Table 1) and the number of cells/mm2 at risk of neoplastic transformation, 27 200 per mm2 (Miller et al., 2017). Since we have a Gompertz function growth curve for male F344 rat body weight (Conolly et al., 2003), the age-dependent number of N cells can be calculated from birth through adulthood. Here we assume that the bodyweight growth curve also describes the growth of mucosal cells in the nasal cavity. The change in cell number per unit of time, obtained with the Gompertz curve, is then used to calculate the age-dependent division rate constant a(t): where N(t,t−Δt) is the change in the number of N cells over the interval Δt, N(t−Δt) is the number of N cells at time t−Δt, and β is the death rate of N cells (1/h). The value of β was calculated from control labeled cell data found in Table 2 of Monticello et al. (1990) using the assumption that the rate of cell division (α) in an adult rat is the same as the rate of cell death (β). In the lateral meatus and septum of rats sacrificed at 21 weeks of age, a total of 150 labeled cells were seen in a total of 2270 cells examined. Using the formula for calculating α from labeling index data, equation 2 in Conolly et al. (2003), α = β = 3.5e−4/h (Figure 3).

The ULLI measurement is of labeled cells per uniform length of basement membrane and thus does not provide replication data with usable units (ie, 1/time). The ULLI data (Table 2) do, however, contain information on labeling in exposed and in concurrent controls for the eight time points at which ULLI was measured and for a wide range of exposure (flux) levels. Thus, for each time point and flux level, the ratio: is available. The product of this time- and flux-dependent ratio with α(t)control is used to adjust the calculated division rate constant for control to reflect the effect of exposure to formaldehyde: This calculation is used to obtain αt,flux for all time points t and flux values of interest (Figure 4; Table 3). It should be noted that ULLI data measured at the 5 sites in the rat nose (ALM PLM AMS PMS MMT) were averaged for each time point and exposure level. The flux predictions for the 5 sites were also averaged. This averaging provided a single flux-ULLI data pair for each time point and exposure level (Table 2).

caption.p: Uniform length labeling index (ULLI) data from the second CIIT bioassay (Monticello et al., 1996) were used to provide cell division rate constants for the BBDR modeling. For any timepoint in the age of a rat, the ratio of ULLI exposed to ULLI control is calculated. This product of this ratio and the control cell division rate at that timepoint (see Figure 3) provides a division rate constant (α) for the timepoint and its associated flux value. If there is no flux, then αexposed = αcontrol.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The division rates in the shaded area correspond to the ULLI values in Table 2 after adjustment as described in Methods. Note that the leftmost column in Table 2 shows weeks into the inhalation bioassay, while the leftmost column here shows age of the rats in hours, the calculation time step of the BBDR model. Every run of the BBDR model recapitulates the entire lifetime of the rat, which is why division rates are shown for ages before the start and after the end of the bioassay. Note also that division rates that are not in the shaded area do not change with flux, as there is no exposure to exogenous formaldehyde at these times.

sec.title: Cell mutation
sec.p: The rate of mutation of N cells depends on the number of N cells at any point in time, their rate of division, and the probability of mutation per cell division at that time: where RmutN(t) is the rate of mutation of N cells at time t (mutations/h), N(t) is the number of N cells at time t (cells), αN(t) is the rate constant for division of N cells (1/h), and pmut(t) is the probability of mutation per cell division. pmut(t) has two components, one due to cytotoxic effects of exogenous formaldehyde and the other associated with endogenous and exogenous DNA adducts.

The cytotoxic environment contributes to pmut(t) by: where KMU_cyto is an adjustable constant (probability of mutation per division) and ratio is a measure of regenerative cell division following cell death due to the cytotoxicity of high concentrations of inhaled formaldehyde. ratio is defined by: where αmin is the division rate constant when the flux into a given flux bin equals fluxmin, which is the flux associated with the inflection point in the J-shaped dose-response curve for α. At fluxes larger than fluxmin, α(t) is larger than αmin, ratio is greater than 1.0, and pmut_cyto is increased in the cytotoxic environment. When flux is less than fluxmin, ratio = 0 and cytotoxicity does not contribute to mutation during cell division (Figure 5).

caption.p: Inset: Average division rate constants α at indicated fluxes. Each average was calculated over the interval from 1536 to 19 031 h after birth, which corresponds to the timing of the inhalation bioassay (Table 3). The data points (x) correspond to the flux—alpha pairs. The fourth-order polynomial, shown at the top of the figure with z indicating flux, was fit to the datapoints in Excel, and used to plot the solid line (R2 = 0.999). The minimum of the function is at flux = 761 pmol/mm2/h and α = 3.932e−4/h. As flux increases, this minimum defines the transition into cytotoxic exposures that result in RCP and associated increases in α.

sec.p: This inflection point was identified as follows. Referring to Table 3, rat age from 1536 to 19 031 h covers the duration of the bioassay inhalation exposure. It is during this time interval that exogenous formaldehyde is available to affect α and pmut. At each flux level (0, 530, 1516, 4544, 7574, and 11 360 pmol/mm2/h) the average value of α from 1536 through 19 031 h was calculated. Using Microsoft Excel, a fourth order polynomial was fit to the 6 flux, aavg pairs: where z is the flux. The minimum of this equation occurs at z = 751, with α(z) = 3.932e-4. Thus, fluxmin = 751 pmol/mm2 and αmin = 3.932e-4/h (Figure 5).

DNA adducts contribute to mutation as: where KMU_add is an adjustable constant (mm3/pmol), ADDendog is the concentration of endogenous adducts during exposure to exogenous formaldehyde (pmol/mm3), ADDendogB is the concentration of endogenous adducts in the absence of exposure to exogenous formaldehyde (pmol/mm3), and ADDexog is the concentration of adducts due to exogenous formaldehyde (pmol/mm3). pmutb is defined as: where xx is the fraction of all endogenous DNA adducts that are due to formaldehyde. Nakamura et al. (2014) reported that the total number of endogenous adducts is on the order of 40 000/cell and the endogenous adducts due to formaldehyde are 1000 to 4000/cell. The formaldehyde adducts thus represent 2.5–10% of the total. We have used the more conservative xx = 0.1. We assume that every endogenous adduct has the same mutagenic potential. Thus, with this assumption, endogenous adducts due to formaldehyde are responsible for 10% of the total mutagenicity due to endogenous adducts as far as nasal SCC development is concerned. The total probability of mutation per cell division, due both cytotoxicity and DNA adducts, is:

sec.title: Intermediate (I) cells and hazard function
sec.p: The growth of I cells is given by: where GAI is a growth advantage for I cells relative to N cells and βI(t) is the death rate (1/h) of I cells. βI(t) is set equal to αt,flux. Use of this equality assumes that, when the death rate and compensatory division rate of N cells is high during cytotoxic exposures to exogenous formaldehyde, both N and I cells have similar dynamics. The alternative assumption of holding βI(t) at its control level (ie, assuming that I cells are resistant to the cytotoxicity) would create an enormous growth advantage for I cells and unrealistic predictions of tumor incidence. C is the correction due to Hoogenveen et al. (1999) as was used by Conolly et al. (2003). This correction accounts for the fact that, in a given population with variability among individuals in the number of I cells, tumors are more likely to develop in the individuals with more than the population average number of I cells (Moolgavkar et al., 1988). This means that, when a tumor develops in an individual, the average number of I cells in the remaining, tumor-free individuals is expected to decrease. The correction is used in equation 7 to obtain the Hoogenveen approximation to the “exact solution” of the CG model (Moolgavkar et al., 1988). The prevalence or cumulative probability of tumor is calculated from the hazard by: when ptum is the prevalence, hazard is the rate of mutation of I cells in previously tumor-free individuals, and delay is an adjustable parameter denoting the time required for a new tumor cell to grow to a clinically detectable tumor.

The correction due to Hoogenveen et al. (1999) has been criticized as failing to provide an accurate description of tumor incidence when CG parameters vary with time (Crump et al., 2005), as is the case in the current work. Subramaniam et al. (2007) found, however, that the predictions of prevalence (and thus incidence) in Conolly et al. (2003), which used the Hoogenveen et al. (1999) correction, and predictions obtained using the exact solution due to Crump et al. (2005) were “very similar” (Subramaniam et al., 2007, p. 1243). Therefore, the Hoogenveen et al. (1999) correction was used for the present work, since it is computationally much faster, as was noted by Hoogenveen et al. (1999), and because the maximum likelihood optimizations used in the present work are computationally intensive.

sec.title: Tumors
sec.p: In the CIIT inhalation bioassays, F344 rats were exposed to 0, 0.7, 2.0, 6.01, 9.93, or 14.96 ppm formaldehyde, with nasal SCCs developing only following exposure to 6.01, 9.93, or 14.96 ppm (Conolly et al., 2003). Conolly et al. (2003) were not able to obtain simultaneous good fits to both the 9.93 ppm and 14.96 tumor data. Reasonably accurate descriptions of the 6.01 ppm and 14.96 data were obtained, but the 9.93 ppm tumor prevalence was underpredicted. Since 14.96 ppm is an extremely high, irritant concentration, and of questionable relevance to formaldehyde risk assessment, we chose for the current effort to focus on the 6.01 and 9.93 ppm tumor data.

Conolly et al. (2003) used a total of 13 control SCCs drawn from a combination of inhalation and oral gavage cancer bioassays in the National Toxicology Program (NTP) database. None of the controls in the CIIT bioassays developed nasal SCCs. Subramaniam et al. (2007) pointed out that, of the 13 controls, 12 were from oral gavage bioassays and only 1 from an inhalation bioassay, a result unlikely to occur by chance (p = .01, Crump et al. 2008). It is possible that corn oil gavage can occasionally lead to reflux of corn oil into the nasal passages, leading to irritation, which is a risk factor for tumor development (Dr. Kevin Morgan, personal communication). More recently, the USEPA (2022) suggested that the single inhalation control tumor is probably not relevant to formaldehyde risk assessment. A complete lack of control tumors implies that either there is a zero-control incidence of nasal SCCs in the F344 rat or, alternatively, that there is a nonzero control incidence but that this incidence is so small that no tumors would be expected to appear in the control group. We have thus focused on describing the bioassay tumor response as being driven via cytotoxicity. In the following, we consider how the cytotoxic environment can both increase the rate of cell division and be pro-mutagenic, thereby providing the necessary conditions for tumor development without a need for pro-mutagenic effects of formaldehyde at noncytotoxic inhaled concentrations.

Reactive species are an important component of the cytotoxic environment (Gentile et al., 2017; Nakamura et al., 2014). Cytotoxicity is associated with activation of stress responses, including those for inflammation, oxidative stress, and DNA repair (NRC, 2007; Simmons et al., 2009). While these stress response pathways help cells to survive, inflammation can itself provide the environment needed for the development of malignancy (Nakamura and Nakamura, 2020; O’Byrne and Dalgleish, 2001). Elevated levels of reactive species can damage DNA or alter the function of the biochemical machinery that replicates DNA and controls cell division. Such damage, when coupled with a compensatory increase in cell proliferation, can enhance the fixation of pro-mutagenic damage, leading to cytotoxicity-driven increases in mutation (Clewell et al., 2018, 2019; Lu et al., 2012; Swenberg et al., 2008; Takahashi et al., 2000; Wolf et al., 2019).

As noted above, the lack of observed control tumors does not necessarily mean that the control incidence is zero. Rather, the incidence may simply be so small that nasal SCCs have not occurred in the control rats. Since USEPA (2022) have stated strong reservations about the relevance of any of the existing controls from the large NTP database (4602 inhalation controls; Subramaniam et al. 2007), we have chosen to limit our analysis to the concurrent controls from the two CIIT bioassays, a total of 322 F344 rats (Conolly et al., 2003). A probability of mutation per cell division is associated with DNA adducts by the parameter KMU_add (equation 7). As previously noted, it is appropriate to consider the adducts as biomarkers of exposure of DNA and of the regulatory machinery of the cell cycle.

Conolly et al. (2003) used a likelihood function in which SCCs were considered to be rapidly fatal and noted that the alternative of treating the tumors as incidental (ie, not rapidly fatal) did not support identification of parameter values providing a good description of the tumor data. Subramaniam et al. (2007) developed an alternative likelihood function where SCCs found in animals that died from their tumors were fatal, while tumors found at a scheduled sacrifice were incidental. This alternative treatment of the likelihood introduces an extra unknown parameter that must be identified through optimization. In our hands, the available tumor data support the simultaneous identification of 5 parameters, and 6 using a computationally more intensive grid search (Conolly et al., 2003). Thus, since Subramaniam et al. (2007) did not indicate that their alternative likelihood provided a better description of the tumor data than was obtained by Conolly et al. (2003), we chose to avoid adding an additional unknown parameter to the BBDR model.

sec.title: Coding and optimization
sec.p: BBDR model code was written in Octave 6.2.0 (Eaton et al., 2021). Parameter values were optimized using fminsearchbnd© (D’Errico, 2021), which allows specification of upper and lower bounds to constrain parameter optimization to biologically reasonable values. Fminsearchbnd interfaces with the fminsearch algorithm that is part of the Octave Optim package. Optim implements the Nelder-Mead simplex algorithm. Fminsearchbnd was used to maximize the likelihood of the data (rats with and without tumors) as described in detail by Conolly et al. (2003).
Parameter values were optimized by maximizing the log likelihood of the tumor and survivor data as described in detail by Conolly et al. (2003).

The full BBDR model was solved separately for each of the 20 flux bins, allowing for incorporation into hazard predictions of the CFD-predicted, flux bin-specific dosimetry of exogenous formaldehyde. The hazards, calculated for each flux bin, were summed to obtain the hazard for the entire population of cells at risk, ie, for the epithelial cells lining the nasal cavity. Computational efficiency was achieved by (a) implementing the equations of the model as difference equations and solving them analytically across a time step of 1 h and (b) vectorizing the model code, which largely avoided the use of for loops when solving the 20 sets of model equations.

sec.title: PK: CFD modeling
sec.p: The total surface area of the rat nasal model was 1704.7 mm2. Surface area of the dry squamous region was 67.3 mm2. Surface area of the total squamous epithelium (including dry and wet squamous) was 172.7 mm2.
Simulated streamlines of inhalation airflow were qualitatively similar to the airflow results from Kimbell et al. (2001a). Mass balance errors for the airflow simulations were less than 0.007%.

Nasal uptake of inhaled formaldehyde was initially simulated in the rat nasal passages at a flow rate of 0.288 l/min to match the flow rate used by Kimbell et al. (2001a), who reported experimental uptake in the laboratory. At this flow rate, nasal uptake was predicted to be 96.0%, within one standard deviation of the average value of 97.0% reported by Kimbell et al. (2001a). At the target resting breathing rate of twice the minute volume, or 0.576 l/min, nasal uptake was predicted to be 87.4%. The mass balance error was <0.14%.

Average predicted flux values (pmol/mm2/h) for the five sites where cell proliferation was measured were ALM, 900; PLM, 575; AMS, 828; PMS, 703; MMT, 779. For the 20 flux bins of the rat nonsquamous epithelium, flux range, average flux, percentage surface, and surface area in each bin were calculated (Table 1; Figure 2). The percentage surface associated with Bin 1 was 61.7% and showed a sharp decrease with increasing bin number.

sec.title: PD: clonal growth modeling
sec.p: Bioassay exposures began with rats about 9 weeks old (Monticello et al., 1996). Accordingly, while the BBDR simulations began on day 1 of rat life (ie, birth), exposure to formaldehyde was started at 1512 h (9 weeks). At 6 ppm, the division rate of N cells was predicted to rise quickly then gradually decline, tracking with the measured division rates (Figure 6; Table 3; Conolly et al., 2002). With the BBDR model configured to run in cytotoxicity-only mode, ie, with KMU_add = 0, mutations during division of N cells, accumulation of I cells, and mutation of I cells only occurred in the presence of ongoing cytotoxic exposures (Figure 6).

caption.p: Selected model dynamics predicted from 1000 to 3000 h in the rat lifetime as driven by cytotoxicity alone (KMU_add = 0). Bioassay exposure, 6 h/day, 5 days/week to 6 ppm, starting at 1512 h. Top left, division rate of normal (N) cells decreases gradually from 1000 h until the start of bioassay exposure. After the initial increase, the division rate gradually declines as the rat accommodates to the 6 pm exposure. Top right, the total number of mutations of N cells per hour tracks with the daily exposure and the division rate. Bottom left, total number of I cells. Since this scenario is cytotoxicity only, there are no I cells before cytotoxic bioassay exposure begins. Bottom right, rate of I cell mutation per division, also tracking with the daily exposure scenario and the division rate driven by cytotoxicity.

sec.p: Optimization of the adjustable parameters (Table 4) provided visually accurate simulations of the tumor data at 6 and 10 ppm (Figure 7). The end-of-life probability of tumor at 2 ppm was predicted to be about 3 orders of magnitude lower than at 6 ppm, reflecting the highly nonlinear dose-response for cytotoxicity (Conolly et al., 2002). At 0.7 ppm, the lowest concentration used in the CIIT bioassays, a small but nonzero probability of tumor was predicted, indicating that this exposure level is cytotoxic in a small, high-flux region of the nasal mucosa. This result at 0.7 pm highlights the value of the flux binning approach, where the surface of the nasal mucosa is partitioned into bins defined by flux (Table 1). Flux binning allows the model to capture the relationship between regional variation in flux and the associated probability of tumor.

caption.p: Predicted tumor response driven by cytotoxicity alone (KMU_add = 0). Probability of tumor as a function of time and exposure concentration using the bioassay exposure conditions. Log likelihood = −250.5. Reasonable agreement is seen with the tumor data at 6 and 10 ppm inhaled formaldehyde. No tumors occurred during the bioassay exposures at 0.7 and 2 ppm. With the cytotoxicity only MOA, there is no probability of tumor for 0 ppm since cytotoxicity is not associated with endogenous formaldehyde.

fn.label: a
fn.p: Used for the simulation shown in Figures 6–11.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Fixed at 0 during optimization. Nonzero value used to address concern for a possible low tumor prevalence associated with DNA adducts.

sec.p: While the cytotoxicity-only mode of action is consistent with a lack of control nasal SCC in F344 rats (USEPA, 2022), it is possible that mutagenicity associated with DNA adducts is associated with a small, undetected probability of mutation and tumor formation under the bioassay exposure conditions. Starting with the optimal parameter values for the cytotoxicity-only simulation of the tumor response (Figure 7; Table 4), the value of KMU_add was increased from 0 to 1.0e-7. This change results in a control probability of tumor of about 1.0e–3 (Figure 8), maintained visually good fits to the tumor data, and decreased the likelihood only slightly, from –250.5 to –251.2. The control probability of 1.0e–3 was arbitrarily selected as being reasonable given the lack of control SCCs in the 322 bioassay controls and in the additional rats exposed at 0.7 and 2.0 ppm. This control probability of tumor is associated with the endogenous DNA adducts, of which about 10% are due to endogenous formaldehyde (equation 9; Nakamura et al., 2014).

caption.p: Predicted tumor response driven by cytotoxicity plus mutagenicity associated with DNA adducts (KMU_add = 1.0e−7). Probability of tumor as a function of time and exposure concentration using the bioassay exposure conditions. Log likelihood = −251.2. Note that the curves for control and 0.7 largely overlap and are barely distinguishable. Fits to the tumor data at 6 and 10 ppm are visually similar to, and incurred only a small decrease in the likelihood, the fits obtained when the tumor response is driven only by cytotoxicity (KMU_add = 0; Figure 7).

sec.p: The predicted role of cytotoxicity in the bioassay tumor response is clearly illustrated when the tumors are assumed to be driven only by DNA adduct mutagenicity, using KMU_add = 1.0e–7 and KMU_cyto = 0 (Figure 9). A key point of these simulations is that, while the value of KMU_add could be increased to support simulation of a more accurate adduct-associated tumor response at the higher bioassay exposure levels, doing so would result in a significant lifetime probability of tumor in controls. Such a result would be inconsistent with the observed lack of tumors in the concurrent controls and with the USEPA’s position on the control tumors (USEPA, 2022).

caption.p: Predicted tumor response driven only by mutagenicity associated with DNA adducts (KMU_add = 1.0e−7; KMU_cyto = 0). This simulation more clearly illustrates the predicted contribution of cytotoxicity to the tumor response as seen in Figs. 7 and 8. End-of-life probability of tumor is predicted to be about 7.0e−2 at 10 ppm, 5.0e−3 at 6 ppm, and essentially the same as control, 1.0e−3, for 0.7 and 2 ppm.

sec.p: The cytotoxicity-only configuration (KMU_add = 0) was used to develop a dose-response curve for probability of tumor (Figure 10). The lowest inhaled concentration at which the predicted probability of tumor is nonzero is 0.3 ppm, with a tumor risk of 3.0e–8. This indicates that there is sufficient CFD-predicted flux at this inhaled concentration to cause cytotoxicity and regenerative proliferation in a small (anterior) section of rat nasal mucosa. Note that, in this case, lowering of the rate of cell division (Table 2) at low inhaled concentrations of formaldehyde does not affect the low-dose risk, since cytotoxicity-driven risk only occurs when the rate of cell division is increasing (equations 4 − 6).

caption.p: Predicted dose-response for the cytotoxicity-only MOA using the bioassay exposure regimen. The lowest inhaled concentration at which the probability of tumor is nonzero is 0.3 pm, with a predicted tumor risk of 3.0e−8. This indicates that there is sufficient CFD-predicted flux at this concentration to cause cytotoxicity and regenerative proliferation in a small (anterior) section of rat nasal mucosa. Note that, in this case, the decrease from control in the rate of cell division (Table 2) at low inhaled concentrations of formaldehyde does not affect the low-dose risk. Abbreviation: CFD, computational fluid dynamics.

sec.p: The dose-response when both cytotoxicity and adduct mutagenicity (KMU_add = 1e–7) contribute to the tumor response is predicted to be complicated by the U-shaped dose-response curve for the effect of inhaled formaldehyde on the rate of cell division (Figure 11; Tables 2 and 3). Below about 0.5 ppm, the predicted probability of tumor is below the control probability, reflecting the dominant effect of the cell division rate over the probability of mutation per cell division as a determinant of the tumor response. Above 0.5 ppm, the probability of tumor gradually increases as cytotoxicity increases the rate of cell division. The tumor probability is predicted to exceed the control probability at about 1 ppm and reach 1.0 at 9 ppm. While these dose-response behaviors agree qualitatively with those shown in the CIIT BBDR modeling (Conolly et al., 2003, 2004), we note that a human version of the updated model described here has not been developed at this time.

caption.p: Dose-response predictions for the adduct plus cytotox MOA. Top panel, A U-shaped dose-response, where the lifetime probability of tumor initially decreases from its control level to a nadir at about 0.5 ppm and only exceeds control at about 1.0 ppm. This behavior occurs because the rate of adduct-associated mutagenicity is a function of both the rate of cell division and the adduct-associated probability of mutation per division. While an increase in adduct concentration will increase the probability of mutation per division, a decrease in the rate of division will tend to decrease the rate of mutation. In this case, the decrease in the rate of cell division dominates below about 0.6 ppm. Above this concentration, the cytotoxicity-associated increase in the rate of cell division increases the rate of mutation. Bottom panel, Predicted monotonically increasing dose-response at inhaled concentrations of formaldehyde above about 0.5 ppm.

sec.p: Leng et al. (2019) found that DG adducts of DNA were not detectable at 0.3 ppm inhaled formaldehyde and below, while these adducts are measurable at 0.7 ppm and above (Lu et al., 2011). Leng et al. (2019) suggested that the innate reactivity of formaldehyde must result in its clearance due to this reactivity as it diffuses through the mucus, cell membrane and cytoplasm before diffusing into the nucleus and reaching the DNA. In addition, cytoplasmic formaldehyde is cleared metabolically (Campbell et al., 2020). Inclusion of an effective threshold set between 0.3 and 0.7 ppm for inhaled formaldehyde reaching DNA does not greatly alter the predicted dose-response behaviors shown above in the absence of a threshold. In cytotoxicity-only mode, the lowest nonzero predicted probability of tumor is immediately above the value assigned to the threshold (between 0.3 and 0.7 ppm) and the dose-response curve at higher concentrations is unchanged (Figure 10). When the model is run with cytotoxicity plus adduct mutagenicity, the predicted probability below and up to the threshold value is unchanged from control. Immediately above the threshold value (between 0.3 and 0.7 ppm), predicted probability drops below the control and then rises with increasing inhaled concentrations as in Figure 11. Overall, the effective dosimetry threshold detected by Leng et al. (2019) for DG adducts does not have major implications for the low-dose predictions provided by the updated BBDR model. We again emphasize that these dose-response predictions are for rats and do not have clearcut quantitative implications for humans. These dose-response predictions are, however, qualitatively consistent with those shown for rats and humans by Conolly et al. (2003, 2004).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We have described an update to the BBDR model for rats (Conolly et al., 2003). The update includes a role for endogenous formaldehyde in the formation of DNA adducts and a significant change in the treatment of controls. Overall, these changes emphasize the role of cytotoxicity in the development of the nasal tumors in rats exposed chronically to formaldehyde by inhalation and downplay the role of mutations associated with the DNA adducts. Other changes in the BBDR model are responsive to critiques of the original BBDR modeling (Crump et al. 2008; 2010; Subramaniam et al. 2007, 2008; USEPA, 2022). It was not possible, in the context of the current work, to address every issue encompassed by these critiques. In particular, the present work does not address issues associated with extrapolation of the rat BBDR model to humans. In the following, we describe how the current work addresses the uncertainties in the BBDR model described by Conolly et al. (2003):

A 3D, anatomically accurate CFD model was used to predict inhaled airflow and formaldehyde uptake in the rat nasal passages. The model reflects updated technologies for CFD analyses from prior modeling (Kimbell et al., 2001a,b). Notable updates include smoother surface geometry, refined computational mesh structures, and the use of newer CFD software and methods.

CFD calculations rely on computational meshes of the surfaces and interior volumes of the model. Kimbell et al. (2001a) used hexahedral mesh structures derived from in-house software. Elements were designed to be as uniform in shape and size as possible but were relatively coarse by modern standards. The sophistication of meshing technologies has increased dramatically in recent years, allowing for high-quality, dense meshes of various structures to be developed in complex geometries. For this study, dense, unstructured tetrahedral meshes were developed that included a boundary layer of prism elements.

Boundary layer meshes are recommended for mass transfer simulations to increase accuracy of CFD calculations near the walls. Higher quality meshes are likely responsible for the lower mass balance errors observed in this study. Kimbell et al. (2001a) reported mass balance errors for formaldehyde uptake as high as 14%. That mass balance error was accounted for by evenly distributing the lost mass over the nasal surface and adjusting flux outputs accordingly. This adjustment was not needed in the current study because of the low mass balance errors.

Predicted maximum and average values over the nonsquamous epithelium (Table 1), were in close agreement with the results from Kimbell et al. (2001a,b). Flux binning results for resting breathing were similar between this study and those of Kimbell et al. (2001b). Regional, site-specific flux predictions however, displayed some differences between these studies. At the cell proliferation sites in the rat, flux predictions in the current study were uniformly higher than those reported by Kimbell et al. (2001a), likely due to overall smaller surface area in the current, smoother model. Differences in the ALM, PLM, and AMS regions were all <14% but differences in the PMS and MMT regions were 28% and 34%, respectively, possibly due to 25% larger surface area of PMS in the older work, and the anterior position of MMT allowing more accurate, higher uptake in the current model.
Conolly et al. (2023) updated the adduct dosimetry model (Conolly et al., 2000) to include consideration of endogenous adducts and the new DG adduct data published over the last decade.
As described in detail in Methods, use of the ULLI data has been significantly modified. In particular, the time-dependence of the data is now retained (Figures 3 and 4).

p.bold: 4. Approximation to the exact solution of the 2-stage clonal growth model

sec.p: Subramaniam et al. (2007) criticized the use of the Hoogenveen approximation (Hoogenveen et al., 1999) but also stated that “…the two solutions were very similar” (p. 1243). A poster presented at the 2006 SOT meeting Stochastic Simulation to Obtain the Exact Solution of the Two-Stage Clonal Growth Model, with authors Conolly, Clewell, and Crump, showed that, in the parameter space of the CIIT BBDR model, the Hoogenveen approximation and the exact solution are identical. We have used this stochastic simulation capability to confirm that the current work is also consistent with the exact solution (data not shown).

p.bold: 5. Assumption that the rat nasal tumors are rapidly fatal

sec.p: Subramaniam et al. (2007) used two time delays, one for fatal tumors and one for tumors found at scheduled sacrifices (incidental tumors), while the CIIT BBDR modeling used a single delay. The values for the two delay parameters are 240 and 310 h, which are tiny compared to the value of 6982 h used by Conolly et al. (2003) and 12 274 h for the current work. Moreover, the value of 310 h for a fatal tumor, seems unrealistic, as it means that a single cell expands clonally to a volume of about 1 cm3 (Kerns et al., 1983) in less than 2 weeks (336 h). The much larger delay values in the CIIT modeling and the current work reflect tumor growth in a highly proliferative environment with ongoing cytotoxicity but also with a significant cell death rate, so that the net rate of tumor growth is relatively slow. It is worth noting that p53 mutations, with associated inactivation of apoptosis, which would shorten the delay time, do not appear to be an essential mutation in the rat nasal SCC (Meng et al. 2010; Recio et al., 1992). Since tumors are detected both at scheduled sacrifices and when animals die or are in extremis (Subramaniam et al., 2007), the single delay parameter actually represents an average value of what in reality is a range of values representing the tumor detection times of individual rats, whether detected during scheduled sacrifice or in extremis.

As is discussed at length in Methods, the revised BBDR model uses a mode of action involving cytotoxicity to account for the bioassay tumors. No control tumors are part of this analysis. The possibility of an undetectably low control tumor incidence is addressed by including a low-dose mutagenicity associated with DNA adducts.

p.bold: 7. Parameterization of I cells (cells with one mutation)

sec.p: The parameterization of initiated (1-mutation) cells has been simplified. I cells now differ from normal cells only by the addition of a growth advantage (gai). In addition, we do not agree that, as claimed by USEPA (2022), there are no data relevant to the parameterization of I cells. Within the structure of the 2-stage clonal growth model (Figure 1) the parameterization of I cells is constrained by the data-rich parameterizations of normal cells and tumors. We note that Crump et al. (2008) perturbed I cell growth kinetics such that, in one case, the predicted lifetime additional risk was 1.0 (100% tumor prevalence) at about 0.1 ppm formaldehyde, which is unrealistic. The selection of arbitrary perturbations leading to unrealistic predictions illustrates the importance of the integration of all relevant information on normal cells, tumors, and lifetime risk, in constraining I cell parameters.

It is notable that Crump et al. (2010) stated that BBDR models should not be used for low-dose risk assessment because these kinds of models introduce unmanageable biological complexity and associated uncertainty about the quantitative behavior of this biology. However, if the biology is relevant to dose-response and time-course behaviors, its accurate description is a worthwhile goal and is not, in any sense, unknowable or unmanageable. The iterative approach to model refinement described above will converge toward the levels of accuracy and precision needed to support regulatory decision-making. This convergence is a fundamental characteristic of the scientific method.

BBDR modeling is data-intensive and is only feasible when extensive data and computational models that describe the data, preferably from a mechanistic perspective, are available. Both the dosimetry and tissue response leading to the adverse outcome should be covered in sufficient detail to capture the relevant key events. These models and datasets should describe dose-time-response surfaces, rather than simply dose-response for a fixed time point. The formaldehyde dataset is outstanding in this regard. Obviously, the investment required to develop such a dataset is significant. When a chemical is economically important and exposure is widespread, then perhaps the data-driven prediction of health risk, or lack thereof, may be worthwhile.

The BBDR model we have described synthesizes the extensive mechanistic database for formaldehyde-induced nasal tumors in rats. The USEPA (2022) considers the nasopharyngeal tumors (NPC) associated with occupational exposure to formaldehyde (eg, Beane Freeman, 2013) to arise with the same mode of action as the rat nasal SCC. A scientifically rigorous evaluation of the risk associated with NPC following occupational exposure to formaldehyde should include an evaluation of how well the site-specific human dosimetry of formaldehyde (eg, Conolly et al., 2004) aligns with the incidence of NPC and of how the dose-response for relevant mechanistic endpoints in rats, in particular cytotoxicity, informs the low-dose extrapolation of the probability of human tumors.

sec.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
